My top differentials at this point, given the travel history and eosinophilia, are: 1. **Toxocariasis:** Playing with monkeys raises a flag for possible exposure to roundworm eggs. Managing NLD often requires addressing the underlying diabetes, which falls squarely within the expertise of an endocrinologist. They specialize in hormonal disorders, including diabetes, and can best manage this aspect of the patient's condition. A dermatologist may initially diagnose and biopsy the skin lesion, but long-term management of NLD, especially if related to diabetes, is best handled by an endocrinologist.

dialogue_history.speaker: Specialist (Orthopedic Surgeon)
dialogue_history.text: Yes, secondary patellar tendinopathy is possible given the altered biomechanics. Asymmetrical presentation is absolutely possible in bilateral ruptures. MRI findings influencing surgical choice include retraction extent, muscle quality, and patellar height.

dialogue_history.speaker: Specialist (Orthopedic Surgeon)
dialogue_history.text: For chronic ruptures with retraction, I prefer transosseous tunnels with non-absorbable suture for re-approximation to bone. Anchors can be used, but bone tunnels are my preference. Direct repair is rarely feasible in chronic cases due to retraction and tendon shortening. Retraction dictates technique; more retraction necessitates more complex reconstruction.
